deck.name: Warrior Skills Level 1 - Common Tasks
deck.description: STP 21-1-SMCT - Soldier's Manual of Common Tasks covering weapons, navigation, communication, CBRN, and combat skills

metadata.title: Soldier's Manual of Common Tasks - Warrior Skills Level 1
metadata.proponent: United States Army Training and Doctrine Command

cards.front: What are the four fundamentals of marksmanship?
cards.back:
Steady Position, Aim, Breath Control, Trigger Squeeze.

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 071-311-2027)

cards.front: What are the eight steps in the M4/M16 cycle of function?
cards.back:
Feeding, Chambering, Locking, Firing, Unlocking, Extracting, Ejecting, Cocking.

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 071-311-2025)

cards.front: What is the maximum effective range of the M4 (point target)?
cards.back:
500 meters.

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 071-311-2025)

cards.front: What is the maximum effective range of the M4 (area target)?
cards.back:
600 meters.

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 071-311-2025)

cards.front: What does SPORTS stand for?
cards.back:
Slap, Pull, Observe, Release, Tap, Squeeze (immediate action for malfunction).

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 071-311-2027)

cards.front: What are the three types of M4/M16 malfunctions?
cards.back:
Failure to Feed/Chamber/Lock, Failure to Fire, Failure to Extract/Eject.

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 071-311-2027)

cards.front: What is the first step in clearing the M4/M16?
cards.back:
Point the muzzle in a safe direction.

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 071-311-2026)

cards.front: What is the cyclic rate of fire for the M4/M16?
cards.back:
700-970 rounds per minute.

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 071-311-2025)

cards.front: What is MGRS?
cards.back:
Military Grid Reference System - standard grid reference for military use worldwide.

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 071-329-1030)

cards.front: How do you read grid coordinates?
cards.back:
Read RIGHT then UP (easting first, then northing).

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 071-329-1030)

cards.front: What are the five major terrain features?
cards.back:
Hill, Ridge, Valley, Saddle, Depression.

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 071-329-1006)

cards.front: What are the three minor terrain features?
cards.back:
Draw, Spur, Cliff.

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 071-329-1006)

cards.front: What are the two supplementary terrain features?
cards.back:
Cut and Fill (man-made features).

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 071-329-1006)

cards.front: How do you identify a hill on a map?
cards.back:
Contours form closed circles with higher elevation in center.

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 071-329-1006)

cards.front: How do you identify a depression on a map?
cards.back:
Contours form closed circles with tick marks pointing inward (downhill).

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 071-329-1006)

cards.front: How do you identify a saddle on a map?
cards.back:
Low point between two high points - hourglass shape in contours.

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 071-329-1006)

cards.front: What is a back azimuth?
cards.back:
Opposite direction of an azimuth. Add 180° if <180°, subtract 180° if ≥180°.

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 071-329-1008)

cards.front: What is declination?
cards.back:
The angular difference between true north and magnetic north.

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 071-329-1012)

cards.front: How do you convert magnetic to grid azimuth (East G-M angle)?
cards.back:
Subtract the G-M angle. Memory aid: "East is Least."

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 071-329-1012)

cards.front: How do you convert magnetic to grid azimuth (West G-M angle)?
cards.back:
Add the G-M angle. Memory aid: "West is Best."

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 071-329-1012)

cards.front: What color represents water features on a map?
cards.back:
Blue - lakes, rivers, swamps.

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 071-329-1002)

cards.front: What color represents contour lines on a map?
cards.back:
Brown - elevation and relief.

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 071-329-1002)

cards.front: What color represents vegetation on a map?
cards.back:
Green - woods, orchards, vineyards.

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 071-329-1002)

cards.front: What color represents man-made features on a map?
cards.back:
Black - buildings, roads, boundaries.

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 071-329-1002)

cards.front: What is the scale of a 1:50,000 map?
cards.back:
1 inch = 50,000 inches (~0.8 miles). 1 grid square = 1 km.

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 071-329-1002)

cards.front: What is the phonetic alphabet for A-E?
cards.back:
Alpha, Bravo, Charlie, Delta, Echo.

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 113-571-1022)

cards.front: What is the phonetic alphabet for F-J?
cards.back:
Foxtrot, Golf, Hotel, India, Juliet.

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 113-571-1022)

cards.front: What is the phonetic alphabet for K-O?
cards.back:
Kilo, Lima, Mike, November, Oscar.

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 113-571-1022)

cards.front: What is the phonetic alphabet for P-T?
cards.back:
Papa, Quebec, Romeo, Sierra, Tango.

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 113-571-1022)

cards.front: What is the phonetic alphabet for U-Z?
cards.back:
Uniform, Victor, Whiskey, X-Ray, Yankee, Zulu.

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 113-571-1022)

cards.front: What does OVER mean in radio communication?
cards.back:
End of my transmission, I expect a response.

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 113-571-1022)

cards.front: What does OUT mean in radio communication?
cards.back:
End of my transmission, no response expected.

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 113-571-1022)

cards.front: What does ROGER mean?
cards.back:
I received your last transmission satisfactorily.

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 113-571-1022)

cards.front: What does WILCO mean?
cards.back:
I have received, understand, and will comply.

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 113-571-1022)

cards.front: Why should you never say 'OVER and OUT'?
cards.back:
OVER means expecting a reply, OUT means no reply - contradictory.

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 113-571-1022)

cards.front: What does SALUTE stand for?
cards.back:
Size, Activity, Location, Unit, Time, Equipment (enemy reporting).

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 071-326-0500)

cards.front: What is the S in SALUTE?
cards.back:
Size - number of personnel and vehicles observed.

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 071-326-0500)

cards.front: What is the L in SALUTE?
cards.back:
Location - grid coordinates where enemy observed.

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 071-326-0500)

cards.front: What are the five protective actions for CBRN?
cards.back:
STOP breathing, DON mask, GIVE alarm, TAKE cover, DECONTAMINATE.

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 031-503-1030)

cards.front: What are the MOPP levels?
cards.back:
MOPP 0-4: 0=gear available, 1=overgarment, 2=add boots, 3=add mask, 4=add gloves.

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 031-503-1030)

cards.front: What is MOPP 4?
cards.back:
Full protection - overgarment, boots, mask, hood, and gloves.

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 031-503-1030)

cards.front: What is the time standard for donning the protective mask?
cards.back:
9 seconds.

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 031-503-1012)

cards.front: How do you clear the protective mask after donning?
cards.back:
Cover outlet valve, blow hard to force contaminated air out.

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 031-503-1012)

cards.front: How do you check the mask seal?
cards.back:
Cover inlet valve(s), inhale - mask should collapse and hold.

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 031-503-1012)

cards.front: What is the M67 fragmentation grenade killing radius?
cards.back:
5 meters.

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 071-311-2107)

cards.front: What is the M67 fragmentation grenade casualty radius?
cards.back:
15 meters.

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 071-311-2107)

cards.front: What is the M67 grenade fuze delay?
cards.back:
4-5 seconds.

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 071-311-2107)

cards.front: What is the average throwing distance for the M67 grenade?
cards.back:
30-35 meters.

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 071-311-2107)

cards.front: What color is the M67 fragmentation grenade?
cards.back:
Olive drab with yellow markings.

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 071-311-2107)

cards.front: What is the weight of the M67 grenade?
cards.back:
14 oz (400g).

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 071-311-2107)

cards.front: What are the three individual movement techniques?
cards.back:
Low Crawl, High Crawl, and 3-5 Second Rush.

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 071-326-0513)

cards.front: When do you use the Low Crawl?
cards.back:
Under fire, when very low concealment is available (6-9 inches).

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 071-326-0513)

cards.front: When do you use the 3-5 Second Rush?
cards.back:
Short bounds between cover when enemy is aware of you.

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 071-326-0513)

cards.front: What is the difference between cover and concealment?
cards.back:
Cover stops bullets (protection from fire). Concealment hides you (protection from observation).

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 071-326-0501)

cards.front: What provides the best protection?
cards.back:
Position with both cover AND concealment.

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 071-326-0501)

cards.front: What is the hand signal for 'Attention'?
cards.back:
Arm extended overhead, palm forward.

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 071-326-0510)

cards.front: What is the hand signal for 'Cease Fire'?
cards.back:
Arm extended, palm down, waving side to side.

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 071-326-0510)

cards.front: What is the hand signal for 'Enemy in Sight'?
cards.back:
Arm bent, fist clenched at shoulder.

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 071-326-0510)

cards.front: What is the hand signal for 'Rally Point'?
cards.back:
Circling motion above head.

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 071-326-0510)

cards.front: What is the first action when reacting to contact?
cards.back:
Return fire immediately (suppress the enemy).

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 071-326-0501)

cards.front: What is the challenge and password procedure?
cards.back:
HALT, WHO GOES THERE? → ID → Challenge word → Countersign → Allow passage if correct.

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 071-331-0851)

cards.front: How do you conduct a radio check?
cards.back:
"[Call sign], this is [Your call sign], RADIO CHECK, OVER."

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 113-571-1022)

cards.front: What is LOUD AND CLEAR in signal strength?
cards.back:
Transmission received with excellent strength and clarity.

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 113-571-1022)

cards.front: What is WEAK BUT READABLE?
cards.back:
Transmission can be understood but signal is weak.

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 113-571-1022)

cards.front: How do you transmit numbers over radio?
cards.back:
Speak each digit separately. Example: 15 = "ONE FIVE" not "fifteen."

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 113-571-1022)

cards.front: What is the proword for 'I am repeating'?
cards.back:
I SAY AGAIN.

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 113-571-1022)

cards.front: What is the proword for 'Please repeat'?
cards.back:
SAY AGAIN.

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 113-571-1022)

cards.front: What is the proword for 'Disregard this message'?
cards.back:
DISREGARD or CANCEL.

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 113-571-1022)

cards.front: What is the proword for 'I must pause'?
cards.back:
WAIT or STANDBY.

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 113-571-1022)

cards.front: What does BREAK mean in radio communication?
cards.back:
Separates text from other portions of the message.

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 113-571-1022)

cards.front: What are the marginal information items on a military map?
cards.back:
Sheet name/number, series/scale, edition/date, contour interval, declination diagram, bar scales, legend, grid reference box.

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 071-329-1002)

cards.front: What is a contour interval?
cards.back:
Vertical distance between adjacent contour lines (found in map margin).

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 071-329-1002)

cards.front: What do closely spaced contour lines indicate?
cards.back:
Steep slope.

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 071-329-1006)

cards.front: What do widely spaced contour lines indicate?
cards.back:
Gentle slope.

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 071-329-1006)

cards.front: What is the accuracy of a 4-digit grid?
cards.back:
Within 1,000 meters (1 km).

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 071-329-1030)

cards.front: What is the accuracy of a 6-digit grid?
cards.back:
Within 100 meters.

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 071-329-1030)

cards.front: What is the accuracy of an 8-digit grid?
cards.back:
Within 10 meters.

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 071-329-1030)

cards.front: What is the accuracy of a 10-digit grid?
cards.back:
Within 1 meter.

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 071-329-1030)

cards.front: What are the parts of a lensatic compass?
cards.back:
Cover, base, lens, floating dial, bezel ring, sighting wire, luminous markings.

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 071-329-1008)

cards.front: How many degrees are in a circle/compass?
cards.back:
360 degrees.

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 071-329-1008)

cards.front: How many mils are in a circle?
cards.back:
6400 mils.

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 071-329-1008)

cards.front: What is an azimuth?
cards.back:
Direction from one point to another, measured in degrees from north (0-360°).

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 071-329-1008)

cards.front: What is dead reckoning?
cards.back:
Navigation by keeping track of direction and distance traveled from known point.

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 071-329-1014)

cards.front: What is terrain association?
cards.back:
Navigation using visible terrain features to determine position.

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 071-329-1014)

cards.front: What is a pace count used for?
cards.back:
Measuring distance traveled by counting steps.

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 071-329-1014)

cards.front: What factors affect pace count?
cards.back:
Terrain, vegetation, slope, fatigue, visibility, load carried.

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 071-329-1014)

cards.front: What is the definition of a hasty fighting position?
cards.back:
Quick, temporary position using existing terrain/cover with limited improvement.

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 071-326-0511)

cards.front: What is a sector of fire?
cards.back:
Assigned area a weapon system is responsible for covering.

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 071-326-0511)

cards.front: What is a field of fire?
cards.back:
Area that a weapon can effectively cover from a given position.

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 071-326-0511)

cards.front: What makes a good fighting position?
cards.back:
Cover, concealment, good field of fire, observation, and covered route of withdrawal.

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 071-326-0511)

cards.front: What does CBRN stand for?
cards.back:
Chemical, Biological, Radiological, Nuclear.

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 031-503-1030)

cards.front: What is the vocal alarm for a CBRN attack?
cards.back:
GAS! GAS! GAS! (shouted three times).

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 031-503-1030)

cards.front: What direction should you move in a CBRN environment?
cards.back:
Upwind and uphill from the contamination source.

(Source: STP 21-1-SMCT, Task 031-503-1030)
